title: You can't eval GPT5 anymore
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-20, Reading time: 1 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.lesswrong.com%2Fposts%2FDLZokLxAQ6AzsHrya%2Fyou-can-t-eval-gpt5-anymore%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/010001996218aaa8-a34f2600-5729-489f-8b80-d3f94bb43d1e-000000/oAXDhTVdU59bw-7iMWtKp0ltAZC7TlW-GKHB0mAS9Ow=423
summary: You can't eval GPT5 anymore (1 minute read) The GPT-5 API is aware of the date, which is problematic because the model becomes aware that it is in a simulation when evals are run against it. There is evidence that models behave differently when they know they are in a simulation. Some models start questioning other parts of the simulation once they know they are in a simulation. The API being aware of the date may be an attempt at patching a safety risk.

title: Full vs Incremental Data Loads Explained
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.confessionsofadataguy.com%2Ffull-vs-incremental-data-loads-explained%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019970e3d754-1f14bda1-e012-403a-bce4-3faf7f0b0e16-000000/AAS1LfGeg_Mj3F-xS9rhbKMG0UxYHf2DMY2IwVR2UkM=423
summary: Full vs Incremental Data Loads Explained (9 minute video) Full data loads excel in simplicity and reliability for small datasets or high-integrity needs, but become inefficient for large-scale systems due to high resource use. Incremental loads offer efficiency and scalability for bigger data volumes, though they demand strong change-tracking to prevent errors, with hybrid methods often blending both for optimal balance based on size, frequency, resources, and integrity requirements.

summary: What's the limit of what can be in a TXT record? (3 minute read) TXT records contain multiple character-strings that are limited in length. summary: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks (3 minute read) Obsidian reduces supply chain attack risks by minimizing third-party dependencies, re-implementing or forking code where possible, and shipping only a small, controlled set of version-pinned libraries. summary: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks (3 minute read) Supply chain attacks involve malicious updates sneaking into open-source code. Obsidian minimizes risk by depending on minimal third-party code, often re-implementing functions or forking modules when feasible. When using larger libraries, Obsidian uses version pinning and lockfiles, guaranteeing a deterministic build process.

title: What GPT-oss Leaks About OpenAI's Training Data
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ffi-le.net%2Foss%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019971936ea2-b8d0717c-c988-467d-bd3c-df4d52df062a-000000/ltblpYY0F6pZZDQCMns2OH_zyWEpRGPPQ89o8Z8ze3U=423
summary: What GPT-oss Leaks About OpenAI's Training Data (21 minute read) GPT-oss' weights are openly available, but the sources of training data are not clearly described in the model card. This article takes a look at the model's parameters to find out what the model was trained on. There is strong evidence that the models in the GPT-5 and GPT-oss family were trained on phrases from adult websites. There is weak evidence that part of the GPT training corpus was scraped off GitHub.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.scalarlm.com%2Fblog%2Fllm-deflate-extracting-llms-into-datasets%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019971936ea2-b8d0717c-c988-467d-bd3c-df4d52df062a-000000/JTYsANyuyBtj_cHCpY6k4p3xifomA5tesERDx88b8VI=423
summary: LLM-Deflate: Extracting LLMs Into Datasets (14 minute read) Large language models compress massive amounts of training data into their parameters. The key is treating inference as a knowledge extraction tool rather than just a generation mechanism.
